Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1
Everyone's tree is going to be different right ? Should this be a meson option like bmcwebHttpReqBodyLimitMb ?

I would like to see everyone's opinion. Yes, I can make this limit a meson option if everyone agrees.

It's true the redfish tree is different, but we can use some experience values. I don't really see a deep level of expand on service root buys clients a lot. We need the new parameter in https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/issues/5058 to be able to execute complex query at service root. So, to keep it safe so that we don't easily run out of memory when executing expand queries, it's better to start with a small value.

> Should this be a meson option like bmcwebHttpReqBodyLimitMb ?

My opinion, no.  This is a security parameter, intended to prevent folks from making queries that they know will run the BMC out of resources.  If someone is requesting something that generates something of this size, they're effectively attacking the BMC, and we should be able to have a default that works for all of us, given that most BMC trees aren't THAT different in size system to system (should be same order of magnitude).

Lets try without it, and see what issues we hit trying to tune this.
Okay. I kept it as is. Gunnar, any other comments?

> My opinion, no.
I am fine with that.
nit, can we call these characters?
Done
?  bool is either "true" or "false" so this should be estimated as 5 bytes
Done
+2 for quotes.
Done
same here, "null" is 4 characters in an output json string.
Done
Please use get_ptr<nlohmann::json::array_t>() to remove the duplicated "is_array()" lookup

Done. 

It does make sense to me that the ranged based for will do a check internally.

But have you tested this somewhere that this saves time or space? And is this improvement significant? Does JSON object has a member variable to indicate the type? If so, the check should be cheap enough, right?

> But have you tested this somewhere that this saves time or space?

It's not about time or space.  It's about being explicit and handling the case where the type is incorrect.  There are cases where it does provide a minor improvement, but they're not substantial enough to be worried about.

> Does JSON object has a member variable to indicate the type?

It does;  The accessor for it is nlohmann::json::type().

> It's about being explicit and handling the case where the type is incorrect.  There are cases where it does provide a minor improvement, but they're not substantial enough to be worried about.

I see. Ack.

> It does;  The accessor for it is nlohmann::json::type().

Okay. As you said if this is about being explicit. I totally agree.
This is a little odd.  In the expand case, we need to measure the cumulative size, not a size that's clamped on the body limit.  Was this a case that was hit in practice?
I just worry about overflow if we don't clamp. Any ideas about avoiding overflow?

I guess that this is not needed anymore. Since the actual body won't be too large, at most 2*crow::httpResponseBodyLimit. So we should be good.

Done
Need to add 4 here for the quotes, colon, and space.
Done
Pending a new testing. Doing that now, I would imagine the result is more accurate now.
Done
The failure seems unrelated
Done
Good suggestion. Done
What about this change?
Friendly ping.
In terms of long-term design, I wonder if we need a json type that just tracks this on the fly.  As-written, this is going to cause a bunch of cache reads of things that have already been computed.

Right, we might need to use a custom allocator.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66969288/how-to-get-size-of-nlohmann-json-object-in-memory

I added this into the function comment as a todo.
